Message.Msg: Edison: A reasonable question. There is a simple answer and a complicated one. The simple answer is that I believe INTC is RELATIVELY undervalued in this marketplace. Unless we literally have an all out crash (and I mean fast liquidation), the capital will slosh back and forth in the system to create maximum pain along the way. The MOMOs have created their pain and then some. But frankly, it is VERY risky for funds to create that pain now because everyone knows that they are a house of cards without any fundamental support and no fund manager wants to explain how he/she could be so negligent as to hold or increase a position in the current context. If so, the capital will flow somewhere. I think any responsible fund manager is using AMZN stock as an overvalued currency to buy stocks that are relatively undervalued world class companies with huge cash balance, huge cash flows and huge margins (there is a reason that INTC, AAPL and GOOG fell further, first and faster from the highs. ROTATION.). Furthermore, the short interest is now piled up in stocks like INTC and GRPN which means the easy money to be made is there via a sellers' strike which forces weak shorts to cover on lower volume. That game will be much harder to play in the MOMOs that are well below their historical short interest levels and literally have asymmetric event risk. The more complex answer is that everyone talks about inflation and deflation as if it is monolithic and uniform. It is not. It is relative. What one experiences is a function of where one sits in the economy. I think I have a pretty good handle on relative inflation/deflation will affect different consumer segments and businesses over time, both domestically and internationally. I think AMZN will be a loser in that environment and INTC will be a winner. One must think not just about the direct effects, but the indirect effects (system level interaction effects). We'll see how it plays out, but I am willing to put my own money (not other people's money) where my mouth is. And, I've generally been right on intermediate and longer term time scales. Finally, I think it is insane to have any portfolio that is not hedged.

Message.Msg: Loser longs, no. But, you do have to have long positions to properly hedge. I'm in a ton of cash, but the Fed's goal and what is really meant by financial repression is to accomplish deflation without a dexline in nominal asset prices. The world's central banks are coordinating to accomplish just that. If they were to succeed, or to fail in a hyperinflationary spiral, your cash plus short approach would, in aggregate lose. Having said that, given that you are short a scam that will get hit hard regardless of the inflationary pathway, you'll do just fine. I choose to construct a portfolio that is robust to all scenarios while allowing for/ enabling supranormal returns under the most likely conditions. We have different philosophies, strategies and time horizons. Both can do well as long as we remain internally consistent and disciplined in executing our approach. Good luck. Tech

Message.Title: Amazon's valuation divergence with other tech/retail stocks will end, sooner or later
Message.Msg: Probably sooner. Ther is no way earnings can rise enough make Amazon a reasonable value at the current PE. The valuation will have to catch up to the low PE tech and retail sibllings. Such valuation readjustments usually occur rapidly, not gradually if market history tells us anything. The herd moves in, the herd stampedes out. That is Wall Street in a nutshell. The negative mention in the latest Barron's ( Nov. 12 issue, p. 42) could be a catalyst for more "readjustment" to a more reasonable price and valuation level. Amazon to match the PE of other tech stocks like Apple, Google and eBay would have to fall 75% or more. A more conservative correction could be in the 30-40% range, to the mid $100s, either rapidly or gradually.

Message.Msg: XGB: It is not a POS. GRPN built a business with ~40MM paying customer with about $2B TTM revenues in about 4 years. It is generating cash and, critically, has achieved critical mass in most domestic markets and is on its way to doing so internationally. Most people do not appreciate the density driven nature of the opportunity -- it is about deal/market liquidity. None of you would trade on a platform that only executed a few trades a day. No company would list its stock on such a market. It is why GRPN competitors have failed so miserably despite everyone saying there is no moat. They are wrong. The local liquidity in the deal marketplace is the moat and it is significant because the sales and QC costs of building out a market are very large. But, once overcome, they are sustainable and provide differential returns (the second player has to overcome the self reinforcing loops of GRPN's already dominant platform, offering lower fees or something else to bolster the value proposition). There's no compelling reason (and certainly none that GRPN couldn't immediately match and overcome) for merchants to choose another provider. It's easy for everyone to say its a POS. I don't see many other businesses that have built 40MM paying customers in 4 years, that blew past $1B in revenue and that generate cash. These guys had guts and not only created but protected LT value with very aggressive growth. I'm out. I encourage all of you who are so certain that GRPN is a POS to short it and try holding it until it goes to zero. I'll be on the other side...
